correction.p: This electronic text file was created by optical character recognition (OCR). OCR errors have not been corrected.
Illegible text in the original is indicated using unclear or gap, as appropriate. If corrected, the reference source is incidated with supplied.

normalization.p: Original spelling is preserved. When noticed, obvious misspellings are combined with the correct spelling as choice in the TEI. Ligatures are reproduced as multiple letters. Original footnote and marginal note sigla are replaced with sequential numbers for each entry.

punctuation.p: Extra space around punctuation marks is removed.

quotation.p: Quotation marks are retained as content in the text. Redundant open quotation marks at the start of lines inside block quotes are silently removed.

segmentation.p: The div type="entry" element divides the text into individual entries.
The div type="section" and div type="subsection" elements are reserved for entry subsections.

list.item: Encoding has been done using the recommendations for Level 3 of the TEI in Libraries Guidelines.
Individual entries and page-breaks are encoded, but column breaks are omitted.
Running headers and side descriptions are not included.
Some font formatting is preserved: italic, small caps, strike through, subscript, superscript, underline. The following formatting is ignored: bold, font size, typeface.

projectDesc.p: All text was encoded for the Nineteenth-Century Knowledge Project to provide a machine-readable edition of the Encyclopedia Britannica to analyze.
Subject-level metadata was added to each entry using the HIVE automated vocabulary server created by the Metadata Research Center at Drexel University (https://hive2.cci.drexel.edu).

samplingDecl.p: This release reproduces the text matter for all entries. It does not include images, tables, formulae, front- or back-matter. It omits volume 1, which consists of "Dissertations" rather than entries.

prefixDef.p: URIs with the prefix fast: point to terms in the OCLC FAST (Faceted Application of Subject Terminology) subject heading schema derived from the Library of Congress Subject Headings (LCSH).
URIs with the prefix lcsh1910: point to subject terms in the volume Subject Headings Used in the Dictionary Catalogues of the Library of Congress, 7 vols., Library of Congress, 1910.
URIs with the prefix ht: point to page images in the Hathi Trust.
URIs with the prefix ia: point to page images in the Internet Archive.
URIs with the prefix nls: point to page images in the National Library of Scotland.

div.p:
BELISARIUS, general of the emperor Justinian’s army, who overthrew the Persians in the East, the Vandals in Africa, the Goths in Italy, and, in a degenerate age, renewed the victories and triumphs which had immortalized the glorious times of the republic. But notwithstanding all his exploits, this great commander was falsely accused of a conspiracy against the emperor’s life. The real conspirators had been detected and seized, with daggers hidden under their garments; and one of them died by his own hand, while the other was dragged from the sanctuary, to which he had fled for refuge. Pressed by remorse, or tempted by the hopes of safety, the latter accused two officers of the household of Belisarius; and torture forced them to declare that they had acted according to the secret instructions of their patron. But posterity will not hastily believe that a hero who in the vigour of life had disdained the fairest öfters of ambition and revenge, should stoop to the murder of his prince, whom he could not expect long to survive. His followers were impatient to fly; but flight must have been sup ported by rebellion, and he had lived enough for nature and for glory. Belisarius appeared before the council wit less of fear than of indignation; after forty years service, the emperor prejudged his case; and injustice was sa∏ctι-fied by the presence and authority of the patriarch. 1 e
life of the venerable veteran was indeed spared; but his fortunes were sequestrated, and for upwards of six months he was kept a close prisoner in his own palace. At length lιis innocence was acknowledged, and his freedom and honours were restored; but death, which might have been hastened by grief and resentment, removed him from the world about eight months after his deliverance. That he was deprived of his sight, and reduced to beg charity in the streets, uttering the doleful solicitation of Date obolum Belisαrio, “ give a penny to Belisarius,” is a fiction of later times, which has obtained credit as a supposed instance of extreme vicissitude of fortune. This idle fable seems to have been derived from a work of the twelfth century, entitled the Chiliads, by John Tzetzes, a monk, who relates the blindness and beggary of Belisarius in ten doggerel verses (Chiliad iii. No. 88, 339-348, in Corp. Poet. Graec. tom. ii. p. 311), which are unworthy of quotation. The tale seems to have been imported into Italy with the language and manuscripts of Greece; repeated before the end of the fifteenth century by Crinitus, Pontanus, and Volaterranus; attacked by Alciatus for the honour of the law, and defended by Baronius for the honour of the church. Yet Tzetzes, the father of the fabrication, had confessedly read in the chronicles, that Belisarius did not lose his sight, and that he recovered his fortune and his fame.
